From yesterday on @zjunyuan Transparency and ownership of winners and losers... Jun 24, 2020 | 01:50 PM EDT DOUG KASS Today's Trades This morning I moved from small net long to between small and medium net short in exposure: * I have covered my short ($SPY) calls for pennies.

* I have moved my ($SDS) long to large. * I have initiated an ($IWM) short. * I have added to my individual stock shorts: 1. Added to ($CAT) and ($AAPL) shorts. 2. Added to my speculative basket of "worthless/bankrupt" shorts.

3. Created a basket of large cap shorts of some high beta and recent leadership names that appear to me to be extended. This basket actually includes some stocks that I actually like analytically over the long term. They represent short "fillers" that might be vulnerable if I

am correct about a near term correction. Look to recent market leaders, large percentage movers off of the March bottom and companies exposed to a new wave of Covid-19 spread - companies like Blackstone ($BX) , Morgan Stanley ($MS) , Disney ($DIS) , Microsoft (MSFT) , Alphabet

($GOOGL) , Penn Gaming ($PENN) , Hyatt ($HLT) and Hilton ($H) . Again, some of these stocks are attractive (at a price) as long term investments - but not at current levels. Color me transparent and flexible in approach. (Note: I will be quick to cover this short basket given
the above characterizations.) 4. I have also shorted several retailers. @jimcramer @tomkeene @cnbcfastmoney @SquawkCNBC @riskreversal @ScottWapnerCNBC @FerroTV @saraeisen @threadreaderapp unroll

The 2020 @realdonaldtrump "No Apologies" Tour continues: Trump to Issue Executive Order to Protect Monuments to Slave Traders and Confederate Soldiers Proving once again that he is completely out-of-step, Trump will sign a toothless executive order next week encouraging

enforcement of laws that prohibit removal or defacement of monuments. The ill-fated executive order ignores the fact that most cities are removing monuments to slave traders and Confederate heroes as quickly as they can. See NYTimes, “Cities Want to Remove Toxic Monuments. But

Who Will Take Them?” As for monuments torn down by protesters before the local government can get to them, it seems unlikely that anyone will be prosecuted for toppling a monument to a slave trader. (“A statue of John McDonogh, a merchant and trader of enslaved people, was

removed from Duncan Plaza in New Orleans and dragged into the Mississippi River.”) And, yet, Trump has resorted to his one-trick strategy of appealing to a small and shrinking base by protecting monuments to slave traders and Confederate. That is a desperate strategy.

He’s got nothing, and has adopted glorification of the losing side in the Civil War as a campaign strategy. Pathetic @jimcramer @tomkeene @cnbcfastmoney @SquawkCNBC @riskreversal @carlquintanilla @ScottWapnerCNBC @EpsilonTheory @lizclaman @threadreaderapp unroll

was focused on local issues. Hmm. It sounds like Trump will have a hard time running as the outsider again. @jimcramer @tomkeene @cnbcfastmoney @SquawkCNBC @SaraEisen @riskreversal @ScottWapnerCNBC @epsilon @carlquintanilla @threadreaderapp unroll

@realmoney The 2020 @realdonaldtrump "No Apologies Tour" continues: The DOJ Treats Friends of Trump with Special Care As Michael Flynn inches ever closer to escaping his two guilty pleas with the help of Bill Barr, it is becoming increasingly apparent that Trump will pardon

Roger Stone. Once again, Bill Barr’s DOJ is laying the groundwork. The DOJ has not opposed Stone’s last-minute request to remain out of prison until September. See WaPo, “Justice Department does not oppose Roger Stone’s request to stay out of prison until Sept. 3.” Trump has

signaled that he will soon pardon Stone—presumably before September. See Rolling Stone, “Trump Signals Roger Stone Pardon: ‘He Can Sleep Well at Night!’.” Guess who isn’t getting a pardon? Paul Manafort, who briefly cooperated with Mueller before changing his mind. The

corruption within Bill Barr’s Justice Department is public, brazen, and odious. The only way it will stop is to defeat Trump and open investigations into obstruction of justice. Trump will undoubtedly grant a prophylactic pardon to Barr before Biden is sworn into office. But the

next administration must investigate and disclose the depths to which Barr dragged the DOJ—so that we can set things right and protect against future abuse. Trump isn’t “getting away with it.” The voters are noticing. Trump’s behavior over the last four months have had a negative

and noticeable impact on his standing in the polls. (Standard disclaimer: The Electoral College elects the president, not national polls.) Trump’s abysmal handling of the coronavirus and his response to protests over racial injustice has been noticed by the electorate. See

Reuters, “Approval of Trump's coronavirus response sinks to lowest on record amid surge in cases: Reuters/Ipsos poll.” Only 37% of Americans approve of Trump’s handling of the coronavirus. Trump is not faring better in his approval on issues of racial justice. See NYTimes, “Biden

Takes Dominant Lead as Voters Reject Trump on Virus and Race.” On both issues, Trump is lagging far behind in support from women. See Salon, “Trump's campaign of delusion hits the rocks — and Republican women are bailing out.” The poll referenced in the NYTimes, above, shows “

Biden enjoying a 23-point lead over Trump among female voters.” State-level polling also suggests Trump is in trouble. See CNN, “Polls in Wisconsin and Ohio bring good news for Joe Biden.” Trump is trailing in

Wisconsin and tied in Ohio (where he won by 8% points in 2016). County-level polling in Florida suggests Trump may be in trouble in that state. See MSNBC, “Veteran GOP strategist warns the Trump campaign should be worried about Florida.” And on primary night earlier this week,

The 2020 @realdonaldtump "No Apologies Tour" continues: On Wednesday, the full range of Trump’s assault on the rule of law came into play. Let’s start with the opinion authored by Trump-appointee, Judge

Neomi Rao. Judge Rao issued an extraordinary writ telling District Judge Emmet Sullivan that he could not hold a hearing on the DOJ’s corrupt request to dismiss charges against Michael Flynn. Judge Rao has a history of writing opinions that have provoked widespread derision.

She garnered the same reaction today. See Vox, “The court decision dismissing charges against Michael Flynn is astonishingly bad,” and Slate, “Trump Judge Neomi Rao’s Flynn Opinion Is Dangerous and Anti-Democratic.” As noted in Slate, Judge Sullivan has not yet ruled on the

government’s request to dismiss charges against Flynn. The three-judge panel of the DC Circuit Court of Appeals effectively told a district judge that he could not perform his job as an Article III judge. Judge Robert L. Wilkins issued a strong dissent, objecting to the Judge

Rao’s assertion that a federal judge interferes with a president’s constitutional authority merely by holding a hearing that is required by the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure. As Judge Wilkins noted in his dissent, Judge Rao prohibited the trial judge from holding a hearing

to determine if Michael Flynn lied to the court. Huh? Under what contorted logic is a federal judge divested of his authority to determine if a party has lied to the judge in a criminal proceeding? The good news is that Judge Rao’s decision is so bad it will almost certainly be

reconsidered by the entire D.C. Circuit. The bad news is that Judge Rao—a member of The Federalist Society—feels comfortable issuing such nakedly partisan decisions. This is the damage that Trump and Mitch McConnell have wrought. Not only have they undermined the rule of law,
they have managed to appoint judges who condone their efforts to do so. @jimcramer @tomkeene @ScottWapnerCNBC @riskreversal @EpsilonTheory @carlquintanilla @threadreaderapp unroll
